title: 108_hr2939
content: The Act may be cited as the "Weapons of Mass Destruction Prohibition Improvement Act of 2003". It pertains to the prohibition of weapons of mass destruction. The "Weapons of Mass Destruction Prohibition Improvement Act of 2003" expands jurisdictional bases and scope under Section 2332a of title 18, United States Code, regarding offenses against any person or property within the United States involving interstate or foreign commerce. The "Weapons of Mass Destruction Prohibition Improvement Act of 2003" expands jurisdictional bases and scope under Section 2332a of title 18, United States Code, regarding offenses against any person or property within the United States involving interstate or foreign commerce. The amendments include defining property owned, leased, or used by a foreign government as a target, and clarifying that the term 'property' includes all real and personal property. Additionally, the caption in Section 2332a is modified by deleting the word 'certain'. The "Weapons of Mass Destruction Prohibition Improvement Act of 2003" further amends Section 175b of title 18, United States Code by deleting certain terms in subsections (a) and (b). It also expands the categories of restricted persons subject to prohibitions relating to Select Agents in Section 175b(d)(2) by adding new provisions related to terrorism. The "Weapons of Mass Destruction Prohibition Improvement Act of 2003" amends Section 175b of title 18, United States Code by adding a new provision related to terrorism. It includes defining a terrorist organization as per the Immigration and Nationality Act and making a conforming amendment to regulations regarding select biological agents or toxins. The amendment to the Code of Federal Regulations under the Public Health Service Act will take effect simultaneously with other related sections. SEC. 3 amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 and Title 18 of the United States Code to include participation in the development or production of special nuclear material or atomic weapons. Sec. 832 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 and Title 18 of the United States Code criminalizes participation in nuclear and weapons of mass destruction threats to the United States, with penalties of up to 20 years imprisonment. This includes providing support to foreign terrorist powers' nuclear weapons or weapons of mass destruction programs. It also includes an amendment to section 2332b regarding participation in nuclear and weapons of mass destruction threats.
